   Mg++:2.6 mg/dL, PO4:3.3 mg/dL
   Assessment and Plan
 PERICARDIAL EFFUSION WITH TAMPONADE
 PNEUMONIA, BACTERIAL, COMMUNITY ACQUIRED (CAP)
 PAIN CONTROL (ACUTE PAIN, CHRONIC PAIN)
   This is an 83 year old lady with a history of HTN, dyslipidemia and
   lung cancer s/p RLL resection who p/w to OSH with SOB and low BP and
   found to have a large pericardial effusion with cardiac tamponade,
   likely of malignant etiology, for which she was transferred here for
   pericardiocentesis. On arrival there are few prior hospital records
   available. She underwent pericardiocentesis in the cath lab, and 600cc
   of bloody fluid were removed resulting in normalization of systemic and
   pulmonary pressures.
   Cardiac Tamponade: Large pericardial effusion with tamponade
   physiology, likely malignant in etiology although the broad
   differential includes viral pericarditis given recent cough. Now
   hemodynamically stable s/p pericardiocentesis, with swan-ganz and
   A-line catheters in place.
   -Echo in AM
   -f/u CXR
   -f/u EKG
   -pm Hct
   -Follow pericardial drain output
   -f/u cytology from pericardial fluid
   -Monitor hemodynamics on tele
   -Contact PCP and OSH for records
   -Holding home ACE due to hypotension
   CORONARIES: No prior history of CAD and no CP during this episode.
   Cardiac enzymes negative for ACS.
   -cont simvastatin
   RHYTHM: NSR since admission, no known h/o arrhythmia.
   -Monitor on tele
   -repeat EKG in AM
   RUL opacity: Read as likely post-obstructive pneumonia, which is
   consistent with progressive cough and dyspnea, elevated WBC and
   infiltrate on CXR. Likely a community-acquired pneumonia. Remains
   afebrile, WBC trending down.
   -CTX and Azithromycin for 10d course.
   -follow fever curve and symptoms.
   -follow cultures
   -Discuss with PCP/oncologist in AM
   R Pleural effusion: Malignant vs fluid overload. Elevated BNP suggests
   some element of elevated atrial filling pressures consistent with
   tamponade physiology, but effusion is on the same side as the RUL mass
   and therefore may be malignant. Given tenuous BP in setting of
   pericardial effusion, will hold off on diuresis for now.
   -No diuresis for now
   -Correlate with OSH/[**Hospital 8333**] medical records
   [**Name9 (PRE) 8334**] Is/Os and clinical signs of HF progression
   UTI: U/A with WBCs and bacteria likely represents an uncomplicated UTI,
   appropriately covered by CTX for likely PNA.
   -continue antibiotics
   -f/u Ucx
   Respiratory Distress: Intubated in cath lab due to agitation and
   increased work of breathing with concurrent worsening acidosis.
   -Propofol for sedation
   -Will wean as tolerated
   -Consider removing groin lines later today if stable so pt can sit
   upright
   Acid/Base Disturbance: Normalizing today with pH 7.42/31/116. ABG post
   cath showed pH 7.26, down from 7.34 in ED with a lactate of 1.3 and
   normal PCO2. Given hypotension in the setting of cardiac tamponade,
   this may reflects a resolving lactic acidosis along with respiratory
   alkalosis in the setting of respiratory distress.
   -follow ABG
   -adjust vent settings as necessary
   .
   Anemia: Likely due to acute blood loss in setting of pericardial
   effusion and drainage. Likely also baseline chronic anemia given that
   she was taking iron pills at home.
   -follow Hct
   -follow iron studies
   .
   Presumed ARF: Mild improvement O/N from 1.5 to 1.3. Baseline Cre
   unknown on admission, but a component of prerenal ARF is likely given
   hypotension in setting of tamponade. FeNa =0.3, consistent with a
   prerenal etiology.
   -follow Cre
   -renally dose meds
   DM-2: Continue home basal lantus dose with SSI coverage.
   .
   FEN: Tube feeds; replete lytes PRN.
   ACCESS: PIV's, L groin art-line, L groin CVL with swan
   PROPHYLAXIS:
   -DVT ppx with Heparin SC
   -Pain management with APAP
   -Bowel regimen with senna/colace
   CODE: Presumed full
   DISPO: CCU for now
   HCP: [**Name (NI) 186**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 8335**]; Daughter [**Telephone/Fax (1) 8336**]
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Glycemic Control:
   Lines:
   Arterial Line - [**2144-6-29**] 12:55 AM
   PA Catheter - [**2144-6-29**] 12:56 AM
   18 Gauge - [**2144-6-29**] 12:57 AM
   20 Gauge - [**2144-6-29**] 12:58 AM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT:
   Stress ulcer:
   VAP:
   Comments:
   Communication:  Comments:
   Code status:
   Disposition:

Based on the provided medical progress note, the patient is an 83-year-old woman with a history of hypertension, dyslipidemia, and lung cancer who was admitted with cardiac tamponade and community-acquired pneumonia. She underwent pericardiocentesis and removal of 600cc of bloody fluid, which normalized her systemic and pulmonary pressures.

The patient is currently hemodynamically stable, with a Swan-Ganz catheter and arterial line in place. She is intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation, with a tidal volume of 500mL and a respiratory rate of 14 breaths per minute.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 12.5 K/uL (normal range: 4.5-11.0 K/uL)
* Hemoglobin: 7.1 g/dL (normal range: 12.0-16.0 g/dL)
* Platelet count: 475 K/uL (normal range: 150-450 K/uL)
* Creatinine: 1.3 mg/dL (normal range: 0.5-1.1 mg/dL)
* Troponin-T: <0.01 ng/mL (normal range: <0.01 ng/mL)
* Lactic acid: 0.9 mmol/L (normal range: 0.5-2.0 mmol/L)

The patient's medical conditions include:

* Cardiac tamponade with tamponade physiology, likely of malignant etiology
* Community-acquired pneumonia (CAP)
* Acute pain and chronic pain
* Hypertension
* Dyslipidemia
* Lung cancer

The patient's potential medical complications include:

* Respiratory failure
* Cardiac arrhythmias
* Renal failure
* Acute kidney injury
* Hypotension
* Sepsis
* Metabolic acidosis
* Anemia
* Thrombocytopenia
* Coagulopathy

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Monitoring of hemodynamics and cardiac function
* Follow-up echocardiogram
* Follow-up chest X-ray
* Follow-up electrocardiogram
* Monitoring of pericardial drain output
* Follow-up cytology from pericardial fluid
* Monitoring of white blood cell count and platelet count
* Monitoring of creatinine and electrolyte levels
* Adjustments to medications as necessary
* Close monitoring of the patient's condition and response to treatment.

   pulmonary pressures.
   Cardiac Tamponade: Large pericardial effusion with tamponade
   physiology, likely malignant in etiology although the broad
   differential includes viral pericarditis given recent cough. Now
   hemodynamically stable s/p pericardiocentesis, with swan-ganz and
   A-line catheters in place.
   -Echo in AM
   -f/u CXR
   -f/u EKG
   -plan to tranfuse 1U pRBC today and recheck post-transfusion Hct
   -Follow pericardial drain output
   -f/u cytology from pericardial fluid
   - plan to remove swan today
   -Monitor hemodynamics on tele
   -Contact PCP and OSH for records
   -Holding home ACE due to hypotension
   CORONARIES: No prior history of CAD and no CP during this episode.
   Cardiac enzymes negative for ACS.
   -cont simvastatin
   RHYTHM: NSR since admission, no known h/o arrhythmia.
   -Monitor on tele
   -repeat EKG in AM
   RUL opacity: Read as likely post-obstructive pneumonia, which is
   consistent with progressive cough and dyspnea, elevated WBC and
   infiltrate on CXR. Likely a community-acquired pneumonia. Remains
   afebrile, WBC trending down.
   -CTX and Azithromycin for 14d course
   - sputum cx
   -follow fever curve and symptoms.
   -follow cultures
   -Discuss with PCP/oncologist in AM
   R Pleural effusion: Malignant vs fluid overload. Elevated BNP suggests
   some element of elevated atrial filling pressures consistent with
   tamponade physiology, but effusion is on the same side as the RUL mass
   and therefore may be malignant. Given tenuous BP in setting of
   pericardial effusion, will hold off on diuresis for now.
   -No diuresis for now
   -Correlate with OSH/[**Hospital 8333**] medical records
   [**Name9 (PRE) 8334**] Is/Os and clinical signs of HF progression
   UTI: U/A with WBCs and bacteria likely represents an uncomplicated UTI,
   appropriately covered by CTX for likely PNA.
   -continue antibiotics
   -f/u Ucx
   Respiratory Distress: Intubated in cath lab due to agitation and
   increased work of breathing with concurrent worsening acidosis.
   -Propofol for sedation
   -Will wean as tolerated
   -Consider removing groin lines later today if stable so pt can sit
   upright
   Acid/Base Disturbance: Normalizing today with pH 7.42/31/116. ABG post
   cath showed pH 7.26, down from 7.34 in ED with a lactate of 1.3 and
   normal PCO2. Given hypotension in the setting of cardiac tamponade,
   this may reflects a resolving lactic acidosis along with respiratory
   alkalosis in the setting of respiratory distress.
   -follow ABG
   -adjust vent settings as necessary
   .
   Anemia: Likely due to acute blood loss in setting of pericardial
   effusion and drainage. Likely also baseline chronic anemia given that
   she was taking iron pills at home.
   -transfuse 1U pRBC and recheck Hct
   -follow iron studies
   .
   Presumed ARF: Mild improvement O/N from 1.5 to 1.3. Baseline Cre
   unknown on admission, but a component of prerenal ARF is likely given
   hypotension in setting of tamponade. FeNa =0.3, consistent with a
   prerenal etiology.
   -follow Cre
   -renally dose meds
   DM-2: Continue home basal lantus dose with SSI coverage.
   .
   FEN: Tube feeds; replete lytes PRN.
   ACCESS: PIV's, L groin art-line, L groin CVL with swan
   PROPHYLAXIS:
   -DVT ppx with Heparin SC
   -Pain management with APAP
   -Bowel regimen with senna/colace

Based on the progress note, the patient is an 83-year-old woman with a history of hypertension, dyslipidemia, and lung cancer who presented with cardiac tamponade and was treated with pericardiocentesis. She also has a diagnosis of community-acquired pneumonia (CAP).

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Hemodynamically stable after pericardiocentesis
* Swan-ganz and A-line catheters in place
* Intubated and sedated with propofol
* Respiratory support with mechanical ventilation
* Fever curve trending down
* WBC count decreasing
* Pneumonia likely caused by bacterial infection
* Pericardial effusion with tamponade physiology, likely malignant in etiology
* Elevated BNP suggesting elevated atrial filling pressures

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Cardiac tamponade recurrence
* Pneumonia progression or complications such as respiratory failure, sepsis, or ARDS
* Anemia worsening due to ongoing bleeding or blood loss
* Acute kidney injury (AKI) or acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) due to hypotension and respiratory failure
* Metabolic acidosis or respiratory alkalosis due to altered ventilation-perfusion ratio
* Increased risk of venous thromboembolism (VTE) due to immobility and indwelling catheters
* Gastrointestinal complications such as constipation, nausea, or vomiting due to sedation and immobility
* Infection complications such as catheter-related bloodstream infection (CRBSI) or ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP)

The patient's treatment plan includes:

* Continuous monitoring of vital signs, hemodynamics, and respiratory status
* Antibiotic therapy for CAP
* Pain management with APAP
* Prophylaxis for DVT and stress ulcer
* Tube feeds with electrolyte repletion as needed
* Regular assessment of pericardial drain output and fluid balance
* Follow-up with PCP and oncologist to discuss further management and treatment options.

   differential includes viral pericarditis given recent cough. Now

   A-line catheters in place.

Summary:

The patient is an 83-year-old woman with a history of hypertension, dyslipidemia, and lung cancer who presented with cardiac tamponade and pericardial effusion. She underwent pericardiocentesis and removal of 600cc of bloody fluid, which normalized her systemic and pulmonary pressures. The patient is currently hemodynamically stable with Swan-Ganz and arterial line catheters in place. She is intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation due to respiratory distress. The patient has a diagnosis of community-acquired pneumonia, and her laboratory results show anemia, acute kidney injury, and elevated troponin levels.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Cardiac tamponade: The patient's cardiac tamponade is likely to recur if the pericardial effusion is not fully resolved. Close monitoring of her hemodynamics and cardiac enzymes is necessary to detect any signs of tamponade recurrence.
2. Pneumonia: The patient's community-acquired pneumonia may worsen if not adequately treated. Close monitoring of her respiratory status and laboratory results is necessary to detect any signs of pneumonia progression.
3. Acute kidney injury: The patient's acute kidney injury may worsen if not adequately treated. Close monitoring of her creatinine levels and electrolyte imbalance is necessary to detect any signs of kidney injury progression.
4. Anemia: The patient's anemia may worsen if not adequately treated. Close monitoring of her hemoglobin levels and blood transfusion requirements is necessary to detect any signs of anemia progression.
5. Respiratory distress: The patient's respiratory distress may worsen if not adequately treated. Close monitoring of her respiratory status and oxygen saturation levels is necessary to detect any signs of respiratory distress progression.
6. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension may worsen if not adequately treated. Close monitoring of her blood pressure and cardiovascular status is necessary to detect any signs of hypotension progression.
7. Infection: The patient is at risk of developing secondary infections, such as urinary tract infections or sepsis, due to her immunocompromised state. Close monitoring of her laboratory results and clinical status is necessary to detect any signs of infection.
8. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient is at risk of developing cardiac arrhythmias due to her cardiac tamponade and underlying cardiac disease. Close monitoring of her electrocardiogram and cardiac enzymes is necessary to detect any signs of arrhythmias.
9. Respiratory failure: The patient is at risk of developing respiratory failure due to her pneumonia and underlying respiratory disease. Close monitoring of her respiratory status and oxygen saturation levels is necessary to detect any signs of respiratory failure.

   Assessment and Plan
   This is an 83 year old lady with a history of HTN, dyslipidemia and
   lung cancer s/p RLL resection who p/w to OSH with SOB and low BP and
   found to have a large pericardial effusion with cardiac tamponade,
   likely of malignant etiology, for which she was transferred here for
   pericardiocentesis. On arrival there are few prior hospital records
   available. She underwent pericardiocentesis in the cath lab, and 600cc
   of bloody fluid were removed resulting in normalization of systemic and
   pulmonary pressures.
   Cardiac Tamponade: s/p pericardiocentesis. O/N some respiratory
   distress, BPs to 90-100s down from 120-130s, but recovered with
   stimulation. Hemodynamically stable this morning in 90s-100s. No pulsus
   on A-line tracing. Likely not a reaccumulation of pericardial effusion.
   -Hct trending down
 tx goal >21.0
   -f/u cytology from pericardial fluid
   -f/u records from PCP yesterday
   [**Name9 (PRE) 8372**] home ACE due to hypotension
   - Repeat echo today to evaluate for re-accumulation of pericardial
   effusion
   RUL PNA: Read as likely post-obstructive pneumonia, likely CAP. Remains
   afebrile, WBC trending down. Given respiratory distress o/n, will get
   pulm involved to consider options, e.g. bronchoscopy +/- stenting.
   - day 3 of Levo/Flagyl.
   - f/u again with PCP and family re: goals of care
   - pulm consult
   - sputum cx
   - follow fever curve and symptoms.
   - follow cultures
   R Pleural effusion: Malignant vs infectious. Given tenuous BP in
   setting of pericardial effusion, will hold off on diuresis for now.
   -f/u pulm rec
   UTI: U/A with WBCs and bacteria likely represents an uncomplicated UTI,
   appropriately covered by Levofloxacin for likely PNA.
   -continue antibiotics
   -f/u Ucx
   Respiratory Distress: Extubated, RR 18 this morning w/ strong cough.
   Requiring 95% FiO2 on FM.
   -cont atrovent, start albuterol nebs PRN
   -monitor on tele
   Acid/Base Disturbance: ABG today pH 7.34/41/87/23 on FiO2 95%. ABG post
   cath showed pH 7.26, down from 7.34 in ED with a lactate of 1.3 and
   normal PCO2. Given hypotension in the setting of cardiac tamponade,
   this may reflects a resolving lactic acidosis along with respiratory
   alkalosis in the setting of respiratory distress.
   -follow ABG
   -adjust vent settings as necessary
   .
   Anemia: Likely due to acute blood loss in setting of pericardial
   effusion and drainage. Likely also baseline chronic anemia given that
   she was taking iron pills at home. Hct 21 this morning but re-checked,
   now 23.4
   -trending down, transfusion goal Hct>21.0
   -follow iron studies
   .
   CORONARIES: No prior history of CAD and no CP during this episode.
   Cardiac enzymes negative for ACS.
   -cont simvastatin
   RHYTHM: NSR since admission, no known h/o arrhythmia.
   -Monitor on tele
   -repeat EKG in AM
   .
   Presumed ARF: Seems to be resolved, Cre now 1.0. Baseline Cre unknown
   on admission, but a component of prerenal ARF is likely given
   hypotension in setting of tamponade.
   -follow Cre
   -renally dose meds
   DM-2: Continue home basal lantus dose with SSI coverage.
   .
   FEN: S/S today; replete lytes PRN.
   ACCESS: R PIV. Will attempt PICC placement today.

Summary:

The patient is an 83-year-old woman with a history of hypertension, dyslipidemia, and lung cancer who was admitted to the ICU with a large pericardial effusion and cardiac tamponade. She underwent pericardiocentesis and 600cc of bloody fluid were removed. The patient's hemodynamics stabilized, and she was extubated. However, she experienced respiratory distress and her blood pressure decreased to 90-100s. She was treated with antibiotics for a presumed uncomplicated UTI and post-obstructive pneumonia. The patient's laboratory results show a trending down Hct, anemia, and presumed acute kidney injury. She is receiving prophylaxis for DVT, pain management, and bowel regimen.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Re-accumulation of pericardial effusion: The patient's echo today shows no reaccumulation of pericardial fluid, but close monitoring is necessary to detect any potential re-accumulation.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory distress and low oxygen saturation may indicate a risk of respiratory failure. Close monitoring and adjustment of ventilator settings are necessary.
3. Infection: The patient's post-obstructive pneumonia and UTI may lead to further complications, such as sepsis or respiratory failure.
4. Anemia: The patient's trending down Hct and anemia may lead to further complications, such as cardiovascular instability or decreased oxygen delivery to tissues.
5. Acute kidney injury: The patient's presumed acute kidney injury may worsen if not managed properly, leading to electrolyte imbalances, acidosis, and increased risk of cardiovascular complications.
6. Hypotension: The patient's low blood pressure may indicate a risk of cardiovascular instability or organ failure.
7. Pneumonia: The patient's post-obstructive pneumonia may lead to further complications, such as respiratory failure, sepsis, or respiratory distress.
8. UTI: The patient's uncomplicated UTI may lead to further complications, such as sepsis or kidney damage.

Recommendations:

1. Close monitoring of the patient's hemodynamics, respiratory status, and laboratory results to detect any potential complications.
2. Adjust ventilator settings as necessary to maintain adequate oxygenation and ventilation.
3. Continue antibiotics for post-obstructive pneumonia and UTI.
4. Monitor the patient's Hct and anemia, and consider transfusion if necessary.
5. Manage the patient's acute kidney injury with close monitoring of electrolyte levels and fluid status.
6. Consider a pulmonary consult to manage the patient's post-obstructive pneumonia.
7. Discuss goals of care and DNR status with the patient and her family, considering her advanced lung cancer and poor overall prognosis.
8. Consider a PICC line placement to secure a more permanent IV access.

   Assessment and Plan
   This is an 83 year old lady with a history of HTN, dyslipidemia and
   lung cancer s/p RLL resection who p/w to OSH with SOB and low BP and
   found to have a large pericardial effusion with cardiac tamponade,
   likely of malignant etiology, for which she was transferred here for
   pericardiocentesis. On arrival there are few prior hospital records
   available. She underwent pericardiocentesis in the cath lab, and 600cc
   of bloody fluid were removed resulting in normalization of systemic and
   pulmonary pressures.
   Cardiac Tamponade: Large pericardial effusion with tamponade
   physiology, likely malignant in etiology although the broad
   differential includes viral pericarditis given recent cough. Now
   hemodynamically stable s/p pericardiocentesis, with swan-ganz and
   A-line catheters in place.
   -Echo in AM
   -f/u CXR
   -f/u EKG
   -plan to tranfuse 1U pRBC today and recheck post-transfusion Hct
   -Follow pericardial drain output
   -f/u cytology from pericardial fluid
   - plan to remove swan today
   -Monitor hemodynamics on tele
   -Contact PCP and OSH for records
   -Holding home ACE due to hypotension
   CORONARIES: No prior history of CAD and no CP during this episode.
   Cardiac enzymes negative for ACS.
   -cont simvastatin
   RHYTHM: NSR since admission, no known h/o arrhythmia.
   -Monitor on tele
   -repeat EKG in AM
   RUL opacity: Read as likely post-obstructive pneumonia, which is
   consistent with progressive cough and dyspnea, elevated WBC and
   infiltrate on CXR. Likely a community-acquired pneumonia. Remains
   afebrile, WBC trending down.
   -CTX and Azithromycin for 14d course
   - sputum cx
   -follow fever curve and symptoms.
   -follow cultures
   -Discuss with PCP/oncologist in AM
   R Pleural effusion: Malignant vs fluid overload. Elevated BNP suggests
   some element of elevated atrial filling pressures consistent with
   tamponade physiology, but effusion is on the same side as the RUL mass
   and therefore may be malignant. Given tenuous BP in setting of
   pericardial effusion, will hold off on diuresis for now.
   -No diuresis for now
   -Correlate with OSH/[**Hospital 8333**] medical records
   [**Name9 (PRE) 8334**] Is/Os and clinical signs of HF progression
   UTI: U/A with WBCs and bacteria likely represents an uncomplicated UTI,
   appropriately covered by CTX for likely PNA.
   -continue antibiotics
   -f/u Ucx
   Respiratory Distress: Intubated in cath lab due to agitation and
   increased work of breathing with concurrent worsening acidosis.
   -Propofol for sedation
   -Will wean as tolerated
   -Consider removing groin lines later today if stable so pt can sit
   upright
   Acid/Base Disturbance: Normalizing today with pH 7.42/31/116. ABG post
   cath showed pH 7.26, down from 7.34 in ED with a lactate of 1.3 and
   normal PCO2. Given hypotension in the setting of cardiac tamponade,
   this may reflects a resolving lactic acidosis along with respiratory
   alkalosis in the setting of respiratory distress.
   -follow ABG
   -adjust vent settings as necessary
   .
   Anemia: Likely due to acute blood loss in setting of pericardial
   effusion and drainage. Likely also baseline chronic anemia given that
   she was taking iron pills at home.
   -transfuse 1U pRBC and recheck Hct
   -follow iron studies
   .
   Presumed ARF: Mild improvement O/N from 1.5 to 1.3. Baseline Cre
   unknown on admission, but a component of prerenal ARF is likely given
   hypotension in setting of tamponade. FeNa =0.3, consistent with a
   prerenal etiology.
   -follow Cre
   -renally dose meds
   DM-2: Continue home basal lantus dose with SSI coverage.
   .
   FEN: Tube feeds; replete lytes PRN.
   ACCESS: PIV's, L groin art-line, L groin CVL with swan
   PROPHYLAXIS:
   -DVT ppx with Heparin SC
   -Pain management with APAP
   -Bowel regimen with senna/colace
   CODE: Presumed full
   DISPO: CCU for now
   HCP: [**Name (NI) 186**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 8335**]; Daughter [**Telephone/Fax (1) 8336**]

Summary:

The patient is an 83-year-old woman with a history of hypertension, dyslipidemia, and lung cancer who presented to the emergency department with symptoms of acute shortness of breath (OSH) and low blood pressure. She was found to have a large pericardial effusion with cardiac tamponade, likely of malignant etiology, and was transferred to the ICU for pericardiocentesis. After the procedure, she was hemodynamically stable, but remained intubated due to respiratory distress. She has several comorbidities, including anemia, presumed acute kidney injury (ARF), and type 2 diabetes.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Cardiac Tamponade: The patient's cardiac tamponade may recur if the pericardial effusion is not adequately drained or if the patient's underlying malignancy is not treated.
2. Respiratory Distress: The patient's respiratory distress may worsen if she is not adequately ventilated or if her underlying lung disease is not managed.
3. Acute Kidney Injury (ARF): The patient's ARF may progress if her blood pressure is not adequately controlled or if her underlying kidney disease is not managed.
4. Anemia: The patient's anemia may worsen if she does not receive adequate blood transfusions or if her underlying bleeding is not managed.
5. Infection: The patient is at risk for infection due to her intubation and indwelling lines, and may require antibiotics to prevent or treat infections.
6. Venous Thromboembolism (VTE): The patient is at risk for VTE due to her immobility and underlying cancer, and may require prophylactic anticoagulation.
7. Stress Ulcer: The patient is at risk for stress ulcer due to her critical illness and may require prophylactic acid suppression.
8. Gastrointestinal Bleeding: The patient is at risk for gastrointestinal bleeding due to her anemia and underlying cancer, and may require close monitoring and management.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's cardiac tamponade and adjust her management accordingly.
2. Continue to ventilate the patient to manage her respiratory distress.
3. Monitor the patient's kidney function and adjust her fluid management and medications accordingly.
4. Continue to transfuse blood products as needed to manage the patient's anemia.
5. Monitor the patient for signs of infection and adjust her antibiotic regimen accordingly.
6. Consider prophylactic anticoagulation to prevent VTE.
7. Monitor the patient for signs of stress ulcer and adjust her acid suppression regimen accordingly.
8. Monitor the patient for signs of gastrointestinal bleeding and adjust her management accordingly.

   lung cancer s/p RLL resection who p/w to OSH with SOB and low BP and
   found to have a large pericardial effusion with cardiac tamponade,
   likely of malignant etiology, for which she was transferred here for
   pericardiocentesis. On arrival there are few prior hospital records
   available. She underwent pericardiocentesis in the cath lab, and 600cc
   of bloody fluid were removed resulting in normalization of systemic and
   pulmonary pressures.
   Cardiac Tamponade: s/p pericardiocentesis. O/N some respiratory
   distress, BPs to 90-100s down from 120-130s, but recovered with
   stimulation. Hemodynamically stable this morning in 90s-100s. No pulsus

   RUL PNA: Read as likely post-obstructive pneumonia, likely CAP. Remains
   afebrile, WBC trending down. Given respiratory distress o/n, will get
   pulm involved to consider options, e.g. bronchoscopy +/- stenting.

   - f/u again with PCP and family re: goals of care
   - pulm consult
   - sputum cx
   - follow fever curve and symptoms.
   - follow cultures
   R Pleural effusion: Malignant vs infectious. Given tenuous BP in
   setting of pericardial effusion, will hold off on diuresis for now.
   -f/u pulm rec
   UTI: U/A with WBCs and bacteria likely represents an uncomplicated UTI,
   appropriately covered by Levofloxacin for likely PNA.
   -continue antibiotics
   -f/u Ucx
   Respiratory Distress: Extubated, RR 18 this morning w/ strong cough.
   Requiring 95% FiO2 on FM.
   -cont atrovent, start albuterol nebs PRN
   -monitor on tele
   Acid/Base Disturbance: ABG today pH 7.34/41/87/23 on FiO2 95%. ABG post
   cath showed pH 7.26, down from 7.34 in ED with a lactate of 1.3 and
   normal PCO2. Given hypotension in the setting of cardiac tamponade,

Based on the patient's progress note, here is a summary of the patient's condition and potential medical complications:

**Summary:**

The patient is an 83-year-old woman with a history of hypertension, dyslipidemia, and lung cancer who was admitted to the ICU with cardiac tamponade due to a large pericardial effusion, likely of malignant etiology. She underwent pericardiocentesis and 600cc of bloody fluid were removed, resulting in normalization of systemic and pulmonary pressures. The patient is currently hemodynamically stable, with a blood pressure of 90-100s and a heart rate of 99 beats per minute. She is receiving oxygen therapy and has a patent airway.

**Potential Medical Complications:**

1. **Re-accumulation of pericardial effusion:** The patient's cardiac tamponade has been resolved, but there is a risk of re-accumulation of fluid, which could lead to recurrent cardiac tamponade and tamponade physiology.
2. **Respiratory distress:** The patient experienced respiratory distress overnight, which was managed with oxygen therapy and stabilization of her blood pressure. There is a risk of recurrent respiratory distress, particularly if the patient's underlying lung cancer progresses.
3. **Infection:** The patient has a history of lung cancer and is at risk of developing an infection, particularly pneumonia. The patient's respiratory symptoms and abnormal chest x-ray findings suggest that she may have post-obstructive pneumonia.
4. **UTI:** The patient's urinalysis revealed WBCs and bacteria, which suggests that she may have an uncomplicated UTI. However, there is a risk of developing a more severe infection, particularly if the patient's immune system is compromised.
5. **Acid-base disturbance:** The patient's arterial blood gas analysis revealed a pH of 7.34, which suggests that she may have a metabolic alkalosis. However, there is a risk of developing an acid-base disturbance, particularly if the patient's underlying medical conditions progress.
6. **Anemia:** The patient's hemoglobin level is trending down, which suggests that she may be developing anemia. There is a risk of further blood loss, particularly if the patient's underlying medical conditions progress.
7. **Renal impairment:** The patient's creatinine level is normal, but there is a risk of developing renal impairment, particularly if the patient's underlying medical conditions progress.
8. **Cardiac arrhythmias:** The patient's electrocardiogram revealed a normal sinus rhythm, but there is a risk of developing cardiac arrhythmias, particularly if the patient's underlying cardiac conditions progress.

**Plan:**

1. Continue to monitor the patient's cardiac status and respiratory function.
2. Repeat echocardiogram to evaluate for re-accumulation of pericardial effusion.
3. Consult with pulmonology to evaluate the patient's respiratory symptoms and abnormal chest x-ray findings.
4. Continue antibiotics for the patient's UTI.
5. Monitor the patient's acid-base status and adjust therapy as necessary.
6. Continue to monitor the patient's anemia and transfuse as necessary.
7. Monitor the patient's renal function and adjust therapy as necessary.
8. Monitor the patient's cardiac rhythm and adjust therapy as necessary.

Based on the progress note, the patient is an 83-year-old woman with a history of hypertension, dyslipidemia, and lung cancer, who presented with severe shortness of breath (SOB) and low blood pressure (BP). She was found to have a large pericardial effusion with cardiac tamponade, likely of malignant etiology. The patient underwent pericardiocentesis, and 600cc of bloody fluid was removed, resulting in normalization of systemic and pulmonary pressures.

The patient's current condition is stable, with a BP of 90-100s, which is improved from 120-130s earlier. Her respiratory distress has resolved, and she is no longer experiencing hypotension. However, she is still experiencing respiratory distress, with a pulse oximetry (SpO2) of 99%. Her ECG shows low voltage, which is improved from the previous study.

The patient's laboratory results show a trend towards worsening anemia, with a hemoglobin (Hb) level of 21.0 g/dL, which is below the transfusion goal of Hb > 21.0 g/dL. Her platelet count is 24 x 10^9/L, which is within the normal range. Her electrolyte levels are within normal limits, except for a slightly elevated potassium level.

The patient's medications include simvastatin, warfarin, and fentanyl, which are being continued. She is also receiving antibiotics for a suspected urinary tract infection (UTI) and community-acquired pneumonia (CAP).

The patient's medical complications include:

1. Cardiac tamponade: A large pericardial effusion with tamponade physiology, likely of malignant etiology.
2. Anemia: A trend towards worsening anemia, likely due to acute blood loss and chronic anemia.
3. Respiratory distress: The patient is experiencing respiratory distress, which is likely due to the pericardial effusion and cardiac tamponade.
4. UTI: A suspected UTI, which is being treated with antibiotics.
5. CAP: A suspected CAP, which is being treated with antibiotics.

The patient's potential medical complications include:

1. Reaccumulation of pericardial effusion: The patient's pericardial effusion may reaccumulate, leading to recurrent cardiac tamponade.
2. Worsening anemia: The patient's anemia may worsen, leading to further complications.
3. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory distress may worsen, leading to respiratory failure.
4. Sepsis: The patient's UTI and CAP may lead to sepsis, which can be life-threatening.
5. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's cardiac tamponade and anemia may lead to cardiac arrhythmias, which can be life-threatening.

Based on the patient's current condition and potential medical complications, the following plan is recommended:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's pericardial effusion and cardiac tamponade.
2. Continue to treat the patient's anemia with blood transfusions and iron supplements.
3. Continue to manage the patient's respiratory distress with oxygen therapy and ventilator support.
4. Continue to treat the patient's UTI and CAP with antibiotics.
5. Monitor the patient's electrolyte levels and adjust medications as necessary.
6. Consider placing a pericardial window to prevent reaccumulation of pericardial effusion.
7. Consider performing a repeat echocardiogram to assess the patient's cardiac function.
8. Consider performing a pulmonary function test to assess the patient's lung function.

Summary:

The patient is an 83-year-old woman with a history of hypertension, dyslipidemia, and lung cancer who was admitted to the ICU with cardiac tamponade due to a large pericardial effusion. She underwent pericardiocentesis and 600cc of bloody fluid were removed, resulting in normalization of systemic and pulmonary pressures. The patient is currently hemodynamically stable, but has several ongoing issues that require close monitoring.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Cardiac tamponade: The patient has a large pericardial effusion, which can lead to cardiac tamponade and potentially life-threatening complications.
2. Malignant pericardial effusion: The effusion is likely of malignant origin, which can lead to further complications and poor prognosis.
3. Respiratory distress: The patient has a history of lung cancer and is experiencing respiratory distress, which can be exacerbated by the pericardial effusion.
4. Anemia: The patient has a low hemoglobin level, which can lead to anemia and potentially life-threatening complications.
5. Acute kidney injury: The patient has a high creatinine level, which can indicate acute kidney injury and potentially life-threatening complications.
6. Infection: The patient has a history of pneumonia and is at risk for further infections, which can be exacerbated by the pericardial effusion.
7. Hypotension: The patient has low blood pressure, which can be exacerbated by the pericardial effusion and potentially lead to further complications.
8. Arrhythmias: The patient has a history of lung cancer and is at risk for arrhythmias, which can be exacerbated by the pericardial effusion.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's cardiac function and pericardial effusion closely.
2. Administer antibiotics to treat the patient's pneumonia and UTI.
3. Monitor the patient's hemoglobin level and consider transfusions if necessary.
4. Monitor the patient's creatinine level and consider dialysis if necessary.
5. Monitor the patient's blood pressure and consider vasopressors if necessary.
6. Monitor the patient's respiratory function and consider intubation if necessary.
7. Consider further imaging studies, such as echocardiogram and CT scan, to evaluate the patient's cardiac function and pericardial effusion.
8. Consider consulting with a cardiologist and pulmonologist to further evaluate the patient's cardiac and respiratory function.

   Assessment and Plan
   This is an 83 year old lady with a history of HTN, dyslipidemia and
   lung cancer s/p RLL resection who p/w to OSH with SOB and low BP and
   found to have a large pericardial effusion with cardiac tamponade,
   likely of malignant etiology, for which she was transferred here for
   pericardiocentesis. On arrival there are few prior hospital records
   available. She underwent pericardiocentesis in the cath lab, and 600cc
   of bloody fluid were removed resulting in normalization of systemic and
   pulmonary pressures.
   Cardiac Tamponade: s/p pericardiocentesis. O/N some respiratory
   distress, BPs to 90-100s down from 120-130s, but recovered with
   stimulation. Hemodynamically stable this morning in 90s-100s. No pulsus
   on A-line tracing. Likely not a reaccumulation of pericardial effusion.
   -Hct trending down
 tx goal >21.0
   -f/u cytology from pericardial fluid
   -f/u records from PCP yesterday
   [**Name9 (PRE) 8372**] home ACE due to hypotension
   - Repeat echo today to evaluate for re-accumulation of pericardial
   effusion
   RUL PNA: Read as likely post-obstructive pneumonia, likely CAP. Remains
   afebrile, WBC trending down. Given respiratory distress o/n, will get
   pulm involved to consider options, e.g. bronchoscopy +/- stenting.
   - day 3 of Levo/Flagyl.
   - f/u again with PCP and family re: goals of care
   - pulm consult
   - sputum cx
   - follow fever curve and symptoms.
   - follow cultures
   R Pleural effusion: Malignant vs infectious. Given tenuous BP in
   setting of pericardial effusion, will hold off on diuresis for now.
   -f/u pulm rec
   UTI: U/A with WBCs and bacteria likely represents an uncomplicated UTI,
   appropriately covered by Levofloxacin for likely PNA.
   -continue antibiotics
   -f/u Ucx
   Respiratory Distress: Extubated, RR 18 this morning w/ strong cough.
   Requiring 95% FiO2 on FM.
   -cont atrovent, start albuterol nebs PRN
   -monitor on tele
   Acid/Base Disturbance: ABG today pH 7.34/41/87/23 on FiO2 95%. ABG post
   cath showed pH 7.26, down from 7.34 in ED with a lactate of 1.3 and
   normal PCO2. Given hypotension in the setting of cardiac tamponade,
   this may reflects a resolving lactic acidosis along with respiratory
   alkalosis in the setting of respiratory distress.
   -follow ABG
   -adjust vent settings as necessary
   .
   Anemia: Likely due to acute blood loss in setting of pericardial
   effusion and drainage. Likely also baseline chronic anemia given that
   she was taking iron pills at home. Hct 21 this morning but re-checked,
   now 23.4
   -trending down, transfusion goal Hct>21.0
   -follow iron studies
   .
   CORONARIES: No prior history of CAD and no CP during this episode.
   Cardiac enzymes negative for ACS.
   -cont simvastatin
   RHYTHM: NSR since admission, no known h/o arrhythmia.
   -Monitor on tele
   -repeat EKG in AM
   .
   Presumed ARF: Seems to be resolved, Cre now 1.0. Baseline Cre unknown
   on admission, but a component of prerenal ARF is likely given
   hypotension in setting of tamponade.
   -follow Cre
   -renally dose meds
   DM-2: Continue home basal lantus dose with SSI coverage.
   .
   FEN: S/S today; replete lytes PRN.
   ACCESS: R PIV. Will attempt PICC placement today.
   PROPHYLAXIS:
   -DVT ppx with Heparin SC
   -Pain management with APAP
   -Bowel regimen with senna/colace
   CODE: Presumed full
   DISPO: CCU for now
   HCP: [**Name (NI) 186**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 8335**]; Daughter [**Telephone/Fax (1) 8336**]
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:

Summary:

The patient is an 83-year-old female with a history of hypertension, dyslipidemia, and lung cancer who was admitted to the ICU with a large pericardial effusion and cardiac tamponade. She underwent pericardiocentesis, which resulted in normalization of systemic and pulmonary pressures. The patient's condition has been stable, with no signs of reaccumulation of pericardial effusion. However, she has experienced some respiratory distress, which has been managed with oxygen therapy and bronchodilators.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Reaccumulation of pericardial effusion: The patient's condition is stable, but it is essential to continue monitoring for any signs of reaccumulation of pericardial fluid.
2. Post-obstructive pneumonia: The patient has a history of lung cancer and has experienced respiratory distress, which may be related to post-obstructive pneumonia. Further evaluation and management are necessary to address this condition.
3. Malignant effusion: The patient's pericardial effusion is likely of malignant etiology, and it is essential to continue monitoring for any signs of recurrence or spread of the disease.
4. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory distress may progress to respiratory failure, which would require intubation and mechanical ventilation.
5. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's cardiac tamponade has resolved, but it is essential to continue monitoring for any signs of cardiac arrhythmias, which could be related to the underlying cardiac condition.
6. Infection: The patient has a history of lung cancer and has experienced respiratory distress, which may be related to an infection. Further evaluation and management are necessary to address this condition.
7. Bleeding: The patient has experienced bleeding related to her pericardial effusion, and it is essential to continue monitoring for any signs of bleeding or hematoma.
8. Renal failure: The patient's creatinine level has decreased, but it is essential to continue monitoring for any signs of renal failure, which could be related to the underlying cardiac condition or other factors.
9. Acid-base imbalance: The patient's acid-base imbalance may be related to her respiratory distress, and it is essential to continue monitoring for any signs of acid-base imbalance or respiratory failure.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's condition closely for any signs of reaccumulation of pericardial effusion or recurrence of cardiac tamponade.
2. Continue to manage the patient's respiratory distress with oxygen therapy and bronchodilators.
3. Consider further evaluation and management of post-obstructive pneumonia, including bronchoscopy and stenting.
4. Continue to monitor the patient's cardiac condition and cardiac arrhythmias.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's renal function and acid-base balance.
6. Consider further evaluation and management of the patient's bleeding and hematoma.
7. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory failure and consider intubation and mechanical ventilation if necessary.
8. Consider further evaluation and management of the patient's infection and sepsis.
9. Continue to monitor the patient's condition and adjust treatment plans as necessary.

   Assessment and Plan
   This is an 83 year old lady with a history of HTN, dyslipidemia and
   lung cancer s/p RLL resection who p/w to OSH with SOB and low BP and
   found to have a large pericardial effusion with cardiac tamponade,
   likely of malignant etiology, for which she was transferred here for
   pericardiocentesis. On arrival there are few prior hospital records
   available. She underwent pericardiocentesis in the cath lab, and 600cc
   of bloody fluid were removed resulting in normalization of systemic and
   pulmonary pressures.
   Cardiac Tamponade: Large pericardial effusion with tamponade
   physiology, likely malignant in etiology although the broad
   differential includes viral pericarditis given recent cough. Now
   hemodynamically stable s/p pericardiocentesis, with swan-ganz and
   A-line catheters in place.
   -Echo in AM
   -f/u CXR
   -f/u EKG
   -plan to tranfuse 1U pRBC today and recheck post-transfusion Hct
   -Follow pericardial drain output
   -f/u cytology from pericardial fluid
   - plan to remove swan today
   -Monitor hemodynamics on tele
   -Contact PCP and OSH for records
   -Holding home ACE due to hypotension
   CORONARIES: No prior history of CAD and no CP during this episode.
   Cardiac enzymes negative for ACS.
   -cont simvastatin
   RHYTHM: NSR since admission, no known h/o arrhythmia.
   -Monitor on tele
   -repeat EKG in AM
   RUL opacity: Read as likely post-obstructive pneumonia, which is
   consistent with progressive cough and dyspnea, elevated WBC and
   infiltrate on CXR. Likely a community-acquired pneumonia. Remains
   afebrile, WBC trending down.
   -CTX and Azithromycin for 14d course
   - sputum cx
   -follow fever curve and symptoms.
   -follow cultures
   -Discuss with PCP/oncologist in AM
   R Pleural effusion: Malignant vs fluid overload. Elevated BNP suggests
   some element of elevated atrial filling pressures consistent with
   tamponade physiology, but effusion is on the same side as the RUL mass
   and therefore may be malignant. Given tenuous BP in setting of
   pericardial effusion, will hold off on diuresis for now.
   -No diuresis for now
   -Correlate with OSH/[**Hospital 8333**] medical records
   [**Name9 (PRE) 8334**] Is/Os and clinical signs of HF progression
   UTI: U/A with WBCs and bacteria likely represents an uncomplicated UTI,
   appropriately covered by CTX for likely PNA.
   -continue antibiotics
   -f/u Ucx
   Respiratory Distress: Intubated in cath lab due to agitation and
   increased work of breathing with concurrent worsening acidosis.
   -Propofol for sedation
   -Will wean as tolerated
   -Consider removing groin lines later today if stable so pt can sit
   upright
   Acid/Base Disturbance: Normalizing today with pH 7.42/31/116. ABG post
   cath showed pH 7.26, down from 7.34 in ED with a lactate of 1.3 and
   normal PCO2. Given hypotension in the setting of cardiac tamponade,
   this may reflects a resolving lactic acidosis along with respiratory
   alkalosis in the setting of respiratory distress.
   -follow ABG
   -adjust vent settings as necessary
   .
   Anemia: Likely due to acute blood loss in setting of pericardial
   effusion and drainage. Likely also baseline chronic anemia given that
   she was taking iron pills at home.
   -transfuse 1U pRBC and recheck Hct
   -follow iron studies
   .
   Presumed ARF: Mild improvement O/N from 1.5 to 1.3. Baseline Cre
   unknown on admission, but a component of prerenal ARF is likely given
   hypotension in setting of tamponade. FeNa =0.3, consistent with a
   prerenal etiology.
   -follow Cre
   -renally dose meds
   DM-2: Continue home basal lantus dose with SSI coverage.
   .
   FEN: Tube feeds; replete lytes PRN.
   ACCESS: PIV's, L groin art-line, L groin CVL with swan
   PROPHYLAXIS:
   -DVT ppx with Heparin SC
   -Pain management with APAP
   -Bowel regimen with senna/colace
   CODE: Presumed full
   DISPO: CCU for now
   HCP: [**Name (NI) 186**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 8335**]; Daughter [**Telephone/Fax (1) 8336**]

Summary:

The patient is an 83-year-old woman with a history of hypertension, dyslipidemia, and lung cancer who presented with severe shortness of breath and low blood pressure due to a large pericardial effusion with cardiac tamponade, likely of malignant etiology. She was transferred to the ICU for pericardiocentesis and has since undergone the procedure, with 600cc of bloody fluid removed. The patient is currently hemodynamically stable with swan-ganz and A-line catheters in place. She is being monitored for cardiac tamponade and pericardial drain output.

The patient has several medical complications, including:

1. Respiratory distress: The patient is intubated and requires mechanical ventilation due to agitation and increased work of breathing.
2. Pericardial effusion: The patient has a large pericardial effusion with cardiac tamponade, which is likely of malignant etiology.
3. Acid-base disturbance: The patient has a mild acidosis, which is resolving with normalization of pH and lactate levels.
4. Anemia: The patient has a likely acute blood loss anemia due to the pericardial effusion and drainage.
5. Presumed ARF: The patient has a mild improvement in creatinine levels overnight, but the baseline creatinine level is unknown on admission.
6. DM-2: The patient has type 2 diabetes and is being treated with insulin and sliding scale insulin.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Cardiac tamponade: The patient is at risk for re-accumulation of pericardial fluid and cardiac tamponade.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient is at risk for respiratory failure due to the underlying lung cancer and respiratory distress.
3. Sepsis: The patient is at risk for sepsis due to the presence of a central line and the possibility of catheter-related bloodstream infection.
4. ARF: The patient is at risk for acute kidney injury due to the underlying medical conditions and the use of nephrotoxic medications.
5. Pulmonary embolism: The patient is at risk for pulmonary embolism due to the presence of a central line and the possibility of deep vein thrombosis.

The patient requires close monitoring and management of her medical complications, as well as ongoing communication with her family and healthcare providers.

   Assessment and Plan
   This is an 83 year old lady with a history of HTN, dyslipidemia and
   lung cancer s/p RLL resection who p/w to OSH with SOB and low BP and
   found to have a large pericardial effusion with cardiac tamponade,
   likely of malignant etiology, for which she was transferred here for
   pericardiocentesis. On arrival there are few prior hospital records
   available. She underwent pericardiocentesis in the cath lab, and 600cc
   of bloody fluid were removed resulting in normalization of systemic and
   pulmonary pressures.
   Goals of care: Moving towards more comfort driven care.  Hoping to have
   her move to hospice.
   -consult palliative care.
   Cardiac Tamponade: s/p pericardiocentesis. O/N some respiratory
   distress, BPs to 90-100s down from 120-130s, but recovered with
   stimulation. Hemodynamically stable this morning in 90s-100s. No pulsus
   on A-line tracing. Likely not a reaccumulation of pericardial
   effusion.  Cytology from pericardial fluid negative for malignant
   cells.
   -Hct stable for now
 tx goal >21.0
   RUL PNA: Read as likely post-obstructive pneumonia, likely CAP. Remains
   afebrile, WBC trending down. Given respiratory distress o/n.
   - day 4 of Levo/Flagyl for 10 day course.
   - sputum cx pending
   - follow fever curve and symptoms.
   - follow cultures (Blood pending, urine Ag Legionella neg)
   R Pleural effusion: Malignant vs infectious. Given tenuous BP in
   setting of pericardial effusion, will hold off on diuresis for now.
   UTI: U/A with WBCs and bacteria likely represents an uncomplicated UTI,
   appropriately covered by Levofloxacin for likely PNA.  Cultures came
   back negative.
   -continue antibiotics
   Respiratory Distress: Extubated, RR 18 this morning w/ strong cough.
   Requiring 95% FiO2 on FM.  Most likely pneumonia and tumor burden in
   lungs.
   -cont atrovent, albuterol nebs PRN
   -monitor on tele
   Acid/Base Disturbance: ABG today pH 7.34/41/87/23 on FiO2 95%. ABG post
   cath showed pH 7.26, down from 7.34 in ED with a lactate of 1.3 and
   normal PCO2. Given hypotension in the setting of cardiac tamponade,
   this may reflects a resolving lactic acidosis along with respiratory
   alkalosis in the setting of respiratory distress.
   .
   Anemia: Likely due to acute blood loss in setting of pericardial
   effusion and drainage. Likely also baseline chronic anemia given that
   she was taking iron pills at home.
   -stable, transfusion goal Hct>21.0
   .
   CORONARIES: No prior history of CAD and no CP during this episode.
   Cardiac enzymes negative for ACS.
   -cont simvastatin
   RHYTHM: NSR since admission, no known h/o arrhythmia.
   -Monitor on tele
   -repeat EKG in AM
   .
   Presumed ARF: Seems to be resolved, Cre now 1.0. Baseline Cre unknown
   on admission, but a component of prerenal ARF is likely given
   hypotension in setting of tamponade.
   -follow Cre
   DM-2: Continue home basal lantus dose with SSI coverage.
   .
   FEN: S/S cleared for thickened liquids w/ nurse supervision; replete
   lytes PRN.
   ACCESS: R PIV. No PICC placement necessary if going to facility.
   PROPHYLAXIS:
   -DVT ppx with Heparin SC
   -Pain management with APAP
   -Bowel regimen with senna/colace
   CODE: Presumed full
   DISPO: CCU for now
   HCP: [**Name (NI) 186**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 8335**]; Daughter [**Telephone/Fax (1) 8336**]
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Glycemic Control:
   Lines:
   20 Gauge - [**2144-6-29**] 12:58 AM
   Arterial Line - [**2144-6-29**] 11:00 PM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT:
   Stress ulcer:
   VAP:

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 83-year-old woman with a history of hypertension, dyslipidemia, and lung cancer who was admitted to the ICU with a large pericardial effusion and cardiac tamponade. She underwent pericardiocentesis, and 600cc of bloody fluid was removed, resulting in normalization of systemic and pulmonary pressures.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory: She is receiving high-flow oxygen and is stable with a SpO2 of 100%.
* Cardiovascular: Her hemodynamics are stable, and her blood pressure is in the 90-100s mmHg.
* Renal: Her creatinine level is 1.0 mg/dL, and her urine output is adequate.
* Neurological: She is sedated and not assessed for movement or tone.
* Gastrointestinal: She has a soft abdomen with bowel sounds present.
* Hematological: Her hemoglobin level is 6.9 g/dL, and her platelet count is 325 K/uL.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is stable, but she may require continued respiratory support.
* Cardiac complications: The patient's cardiac tamponade has been resolved, but she may still have underlying cardiac issues.
* Renal failure: The patient's creatinine level is elevated, and she may require further monitoring and management.
* Infection: The patient has a history of pneumonia and may be at risk for further infections.
* Bleeding: The patient has had a significant amount of blood loss due to the pericardial effusion and may be at risk for further bleeding.
* Anemia: The patient's hemoglobin level is low, and she may require transfusions.

The patient's goals of care are focused on comfort and palliative care, and the healthcare team is working to achieve this goal. The patient's family has requested that no invasive procedures be performed, and the patient has a DNR status.

The patient's medical decision-making capacity is compromised due to her sedation and underlying medical condition. Therefore, the healthcare team will need to work closely with the patient's family to make decisions on her behalf.

Overall, the patient's condition is stable, but she requires continued close monitoring and management to prevent potential complications.

   Assessment and Plan
   This is an 83 year old lady with a history of HTN, dyslipidemia and
   lung cancer s/p RLL resection who p/w to OSH with SOB and low BP and
   found to have a large pericardial effusion with cardiac tamponade,
   likely of malignant etiology, for which she was transferred here for
   pericardiocentesis. On arrival there are few prior hospital records
   available. She underwent pericardiocentesis in the cath lab, and 600cc
   of bloody fluid were removed resulting in normalization of systemic and
   pulmonary pressures.
   Goals of care: Moving towards more comfort driven care.  Hoping to have
   her move to hospice.
   -consult palliative care.
   Cardiac Tamponade: s/p pericardiocentesis. O/N some respiratory
   distress, BPs to 90-100s down from 120-130s, but recovered with
   stimulation. Hemodynamically stable this morning in 90s-100s. No pulsus
   on A-line tracing. Likely not a reaccumulation of pericardial
   effusion.  Cytology from pericardial fluid negative for malignant
   cells.
   -Hct stable for now
 tx goal >21.0
   RUL PNA: Read as likely post-obstructive pneumonia, likely CAP. Remains
   afebrile, WBC trending down. Given respiratory distress o/n.
   - day 4 of Levo/Flagyl for 10 day course.
   - sputum cx pending
   - follow fever curve and symptoms.
   - follow cultures (Blood pending, urine Ag Legionella neg)
   R Pleural effusion: Malignant vs infectious. Given tenuous BP in
   setting of pericardial effusion, will hold off on diuresis for now.
   UTI: U/A with WBCs and bacteria likely represents an uncomplicated UTI,
   appropriately covered by Levofloxacin for likely PNA.  Cultures came
   back negative.
   -continue antibiotics
   Respiratory Distress: Extubated, RR 18 this morning w/ strong cough.
   Requiring 95% FiO2 on FM.  Most likely pneumonia and tumor burden in
   lungs.
   -cont atrovent, albuterol nebs PRN
   -monitor on tele
   Acid/Base Disturbance: ABG today pH 7.34/41/87/23 on FiO2 95%. ABG post
   cath showed pH 7.26, down from 7.34 in ED with a lactate of 1.3 and
   normal PCO2. Given hypotension in the setting of cardiac tamponade,
   this may reflects a resolving lactic acidosis along with respiratory
   alkalosis in the setting of respiratory distress.
   .
   Anemia: Likely due to acute blood loss in setting of pericardial
   effusion and drainage. Likely also baseline chronic anemia given that
   she was taking iron pills at home.
   -stable, transfusion goal Hct>21.0
   .
   CORONARIES: No prior history of CAD and no CP during this episode.
   Cardiac enzymes negative for ACS.
   -cont simvastatin
   RHYTHM: NSR since admission, no known h/o arrhythmia.
   -Monitor on tele
   -repeat EKG in AM
   .
   Presumed ARF: Seems to be resolved, Cre now 1.0. Baseline Cre unknown
   on admission, but a component of prerenal ARF is likely given
   hypotension in setting of tamponade.
   -follow Cre
   DM-2: Continue home basal lantus dose with SSI coverage.
   .

   lytes PRN.

Summary:

The patient is an 83-year-old woman with a history of hypertension, dyslipidemia, and lung cancer who presented with orthostatic hypotension, shortness of breath, and a large pericardial effusion with cardiac tamponade. She underwent pericardiocentesis and 600cc of bloody fluid was removed, resulting in normalization of systemic and pulmonary pressures. The patient is currently being managed with comfort-driven care and is being considered for hospice.

Potential medical complications:

1. Respiratory distress: The patient is experiencing respiratory distress, which may worsen if not managed properly.
2. Pneumonia: The patient has a likely post-obstructive pneumonia, which may progress if not treated effectively.
3. Malignant pleural effusion: The patient has a malignant pleural effusion, which may require further management.
4. Urinary tract infection: The patient has a urinary tract infection, which may require further treatment.
5. Anemia: The patient has anemia, which may require transfusion.
6. Acid-base disturbance: The patient has an acid-base disturbance, which may require further management.
7. Cardiac tamponade: The patient has cardiac tamponade, which may require further management.
8. Renal failure: The patient has presumed acute renal failure, which may require further management.
9. Hyperglycemia: The patient has hyperglycemia, which may require further management.

The patient's condition is complex and requires close monitoring and management to prevent potential complications.

   This is an 83 year old lady with a history of HTN, dyslipidemia and
   lung cancer s/p RLL resection who p/w to OSH with SOB and low BP and
   found to have a large pericardial effusion with cardiac tamponade,
   likely of malignant etiology, for which she was transferred here for
   pericardiocentesis. On arrival there are few prior hospital records
   available. She underwent pericardiocentesis in the cath lab, and 600cc
   of bloody fluid were removed resulting in normalization of systemic and
   pulmonary pressures.
   Cardiac Tamponade: s/p pericardiocentesis. O/N some respiratory
   distress, BPs to 90-100s down from 120-130s, but recovered with
   stimulation. Hemodynamically stable this morning in 90s-100s. No pulsus
   on A-line tracing. Likely not a reaccumulation of pericardial effusion.

 tx goal >21.0

   -f/u records from PCP yesterday

   - Repeat echo today to evaluate for re-accumulation of pericardial
   effusion
   RUL PNA: Read as likely post-obstructive pneumonia, likely CAP. Remains
   afebrile, WBC trending down. Given respiratory distress o/n, will get
   pulm involved to consider options, e.g. bronchoscopy +/- stenting.

   - f/u again with PCP and family re: goals of care

   appropriately covered by Levofloxacin for likely PNA.

   -cont atrovent, start albuterol nebs PRN
   -monitor on tele
   Acid/Base Disturbance: ABG today pH 7.34/41/87/23 on FiO2 95%. ABG post
   cath showed pH 7.26, down from 7.34 in ED with a lactate of 1.3 and
   normal PCO2. Given hypotension in the setting of cardiac tamponade,
   this may reflects a resolving lactic acidosis along with respiratory
   alkalosis in the setting of respiratory distress.
   -follow ABG
   -adjust vent settings as necessary
   .
   Anemia: Likely due to acute blood loss in setting of pericardial
   effusion and drainage. Likely also baseline chronic anemia given that
   she was taking iron pills at home. Hct 21 this morning but re-checked,
   now 23.4
   -trending down, transfusion goal Hct>21.0
   -follow iron studies
   .
   CORONARIES: No prior history of CAD and no CP during this episode.
   Cardiac enzymes negative for ACS.
   -cont simvastatin
   RHYTHM: NSR since admission, no known h/o arrhythmia.
   -Monitor on tele
   -repeat EKG in AM
   .
   Presumed ARF: Seems to be resolved, Cre now 1.0. Baseline Cre unknown
   on admission, but a component of prerenal ARF is likely given
   hypotension in setting of tamponade.
   -follow Cre
   -renally dose meds
   DM-2: Continue home basal lantus dose with SSI coverage.
   .
   FEN: S/S today; replete lytes PRN.
   ACCESS: R PIV. Will attempt PICC placement today.

   -Pain management with APAP
   -Bowel regimen with senna/colace

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 83-year-old lady with a history of hypertension, dyslipidemia, and lung cancer who was admitted to the ICU with a large pericardial effusion with cardiac tamponade, likely of malignant etiology. She underwent pericardiocentesis and 600cc of bloody fluid were removed, resulting in normalization of systemic and pulmonary pressures.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Vital signs: Tmax 37.1C, Tcurrent 36.2C, HR 92 bpm, BP 111/57 mmHg, RR 17 inspirations per minute, SpO2 100%.
* Respiratory support: High-flow nasal cannula (HFNC) with FiO2 95%.
* Laboratory results:
	+ Hemoglobin (Hb) 12.3 g/dL
	+ Hematocrit (Hct) 23.4%
	+ White blood cell count (WBC) 12.3 x 10^9/L
	+ Platelet count (Plt) 325 x 10^9/L
	+ Blood urea nitrogen (BUN) 20 mg/dL
	+ Creatinine (Cr) 1.0 mg/dL
	+ Sodium (Na) 145 mmol/L
	+ Potassium (K) 4.5 mmol/L
	+ Chloride (Cl) 117 mmol/L
	+ Carbon dioxide (CO2) 22.5 mmol/L
* Physical examination: The patient is overweight/obese, with diffuse coarse rhonchi anteriorly, and absent right and left radial pulses.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's current condition include:

* Re-accumulation of pericardial effusion
* Respiratory distress due to pneumonia or other respiratory complications
* Anemia and bleeding due to the pericardial effusion and drainage
* Acute kidney injury (AKI) or acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS)
* Sepsis or septic shock due to the presence of a central line and the patient's immunocompromised state
* Pneumonia or other respiratory infections due to the patient's underlying lung cancer and immunocompromised state
* Cardiac arrhythmias or cardiac tamponade due to the pericardial effusion and drainage
* Malignant pleural effusion or other pleural complications

The patient's family has expressed a desire for non-invasive care, but they do not want bronchoscopy or an NG-tube at this time, and they prefer DNR/DNI. The patient's husband has been responsible for her care, and she has been living alone with him.

   Assessment and Plan
   This is an 83 year old lady with a history of HTN, dyslipidemia and
   lung cancer s/p RLL resection who p/w to OSH with SOB and low BP and
   found to have a large pericardial effusion with cardiac tamponade,
   likely of malignant etiology, for which she was transferred here for
   pericardiocentesis. On arrival there are few prior hospital records
   available. She underwent pericardiocentesis in the cath lab, and 600cc
   of bloody fluid were removed resulting in normalization of systemic and
   pulmonary pressures.
   Goals of care: Moving towards more comfort driven care.  Hoping to have
   her move to hospice.
   -consult palliative care.
   Cardiac Tamponade: s/p pericardiocentesis. O/N some respiratory
   distress, BPs to 90-100s down from 120-130s, but recovered with
   stimulation. Hemodynamically stable this morning in 90s-100s. No pulsus
   on A-line tracing. Likely not a reaccumulation of pericardial effusion.
    Cytology from pericardial fluid negative for malignant cells.
   -Hct trending down
 tx goal >21.0
   RUL PNA: Read as likely post-obstructive pneumonia, likely CAP. Remains
   afebrile, WBC trending down. Given respiratory distress o/n.
   - day 3 of Levo/Flagyl for 10 day course.
   - f/u again with PCP and family re: goals of care
   - pulm consult
   - sputum cx
   - follow fever curve and symptoms.
   - follow cultures
   R Pleural effusion: Malignant vs infectious. Given tenuous BP in
   setting of pericardial effusion, will hold off on diuresis for now.
   UTI: U/A with WBCs and bacteria likely represents an uncomplicated UTI,
   appropriately covered by Levofloxacin for likely PNA.  Cultures came
   back negative.
   -continue antibiotics
   Respiratory Distress: Extubated, RR 18 this morning w/ strong cough.
   Requiring 95% FiO2 on FM.  Most likely pneumonia and tumor burden in
   lungs.
   -cont atrovent, start albuterol nebs PRN
   -monitor on tele
   Acid/Base Disturbance: ABG today pH 7.34/41/87/23 on FiO2 95%. ABG post
   cath showed pH 7.26, down from 7.34 in ED with a lactate of 1.3 and
   normal PCO2. Given hypotension in the setting of cardiac tamponade,
   this may reflects a resolving lactic acidosis along with respiratory
   alkalosis in the setting of respiratory distress.
   .
   Anemia: Likely due to acute blood loss in setting of pericardial
   effusion and drainage. Likely also baseline chronic anemia given that
   she was taking iron pills at home.
   -trending down, transfusion goal Hct>21.0
   -follow iron studies
   .
   CORONARIES: No prior history of CAD and no CP during this episode.
   Cardiac enzymes negative for ACS.
   -cont simvastatin
   RHYTHM: NSR since admission, no known h/o arrhythmia.
   -Monitor on tele
   -repeat EKG in AM
   .
   Presumed ARF: Seems to be resolved, Cre now 1.0. Baseline Cre unknown
   on admission, but a component of prerenal ARF is likely given
   hypotension in setting of tamponade.
   -follow Cre
   DM-2: Continue home basal lantus dose with SSI coverage.
   .
   FEN: S/S today; replete lytes PRN.
   ACCESS: R PIV. Will attempt PICC placement today.
   PROPHYLAXIS:
   -DVT ppx with Heparin SC
   -Pain management with APAP
   -Bowel regimen with senna/colace
   CODE: Presumed full
   DISPO: CCU for now

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is an 83-year-old woman with a history of hypertension, dyslipidemia, and lung cancer who was admitted with a large pericardial effusion and cardiac tamponade. She underwent pericardiocentesis and 600cc of bloody fluid was removed, resulting in normalization of systemic and pulmonary pressures.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory: She is experiencing respiratory distress, with a requirement for 95% FiO2 on FM. Her ABG shows pH 7.34, with a lactate level of 0.6 mmol/L. She has a history of lung cancer and is likely experiencing pneumonia and tumor burden in her lungs.
* Cardiovascular: She has a large pericardial effusion with cardiac tamponade, which was treated with pericardiocentesis. Her cardiac enzymes are negative for acute coronary syndrome, and she has no prior history of coronary artery disease.
* Hemodynamic: Her blood pressure is stable, ranging from 90-100 mmHg, and her heart rate is 92 bpm.
* Renal: Her creatinine level is 1.0 mg/dL, which is likely due to prerenal azotemia caused by hypotension in the setting of cardiac tamponade.
* Anemia: Her hemoglobin level is trending down, likely due to acute blood loss in the setting of pericardial effusion and drainage, as well as baseline chronic anemia.
* Infectious: She has a urinary tract infection, which is likely uncomplicated, and is being treated with antibiotics.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

* Respiratory failure: Given her respiratory distress and requirement for high FiO2, there is a risk of respiratory failure.
* Cardiac tamponade: Although the patient has undergone pericardiocentesis, there is still a risk of reaccumulation of pericardial effusion.
* Pneumonia: The patient has a history of lung cancer and is likely experiencing pneumonia, which can worsen her respiratory status.
* Anemia: The patient's anemia may worsen if not treated, leading to decreased oxygen delivery to her tissues.
* Renal failure: The patient's creatinine level is elevated, and if not managed properly, there is a risk of acute kidney injury or chronic kidney disease.
* Sepsis: The patient's urinary tract infection and pneumonia put her at risk of developing sepsis.

The patient's goals of care are moving towards more comfort-driven care, with a focus on symptom management and palliation. The patient's family has declined bronchoscopy and NG-tube placement, and prefers DNR/DNI status. The patient's condition is being closely monitored, and further management will be guided by her response to treatment and changes in her clinical status.

   R Pleural effusion: Malignant vs infectious. Given tenuous
   hemodynamics, will not diurese at this time.
   UTI: U/A with WBCs and bacteria likely represents an uncomplicated UTI,
   appropriately covered by Levofloxacin for likely PNA.  Cultures came
   back negative.
   -continue antibiotics
   Respiratory Distress: Extubated, RR 18 this morning w/ strong cough.
   Requiring 95% FiO2 on FM.  Most likely pneumonia and tumor burden in
   lungs. Responds to calming and suctioning
   -cont atrovent, albuterol nebs PRN
   Acid/Base Disturbance: ABG today pH 7.34/41/87/23 on FiO2 95%. ABG post
   cath showed pH 7.26, down from 7.34 in ED with a lactate of 1.3 and
   normal PCO2. Given hypotension in the setting of cardiac tamponade,
   this may reflects a resolving lactic acidosis along with respiratory
   alkalosis in the setting of respiratory distress.
   .
   Anemia: Likely due to acute blood loss in setting of pericardial
   effusion and drainage. Likely also baseline chronic anemia given that
   she was taking iron pills at home.  Hct has been stable, today 24.0.
   -stable, transfusion goal Hct>21.0

   Cardiac enzymes negative for ACS.  Off simvastatin given comfort focus

   hypotension in setting of tamponade.

   DM-2: Continue home basal lantus dose with SSI coverage.
   .

Summary:

The patient is an 83-year-old woman with a history of hypertension, dyslipidemia, and lung cancer, who was admitted to the ICU with cardiac tamponade due to a large pericardial effusion. She underwent pericardiocentesis and 600cc of bloody fluid was removed, resulting in normalization of systemic and pulmonary pressures. The patient's goals of care have shifted towards comfort-driven care, and she is being prepared for transfer to a hospice near her home.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Vital signs: Tmax 36.6C, Tcurrent 36.3C, HR 97 bpm, BP 106/44 mmHg, RR 19 insp/min, SpO2 100%
* Hemodynamic monitoring: Hemodynamically stable
* Respiratory support: High-flow nasal cannula, 95% FiO2
* Cardiovascular: Cardiac tamponade has been treated, but the patient still has a large pleural effusion
* Pulmonary: RUL PNA is likely post-obstructive pneumonia, and sputum culture shows rare yeast
* Renal: Presumed ARF has resolved, but the patient has chronic anemia and is at risk for further anemia
* Neurological: Alert and oriented x2
* Laboratory results: WBC 12.3, Hct 24.5, Plt 16, Cr 1.0, TCO2 21, Glucose 82

Potential medical complications:

* Respiratory distress: The patient's respiratory status is still unstable, and she may require further respiratory support.
* Cardiac tamponade: The patient's cardiac tamponade has been treated, but the large pleural effusion may still be causing hemodynamic instability.
* Pneumonia: The patient's RUL PNA is likely post-obstructive pneumonia, and she may require further antibiotic treatment.
* Anemia: The patient has chronic anemia and is at risk for further anemia due to ongoing bleeding or blood loss.
* Renal dysfunction: The patient's presumed ARF has resolved, but she may still be at risk for further renal dysfunction due to underlying chronic kidney disease.
* Infection: The patient's sputum culture shows rare yeast, and she may be at risk for further infection due to her immunocompromised state.
* Pain management: The patient is experiencing pain at the drain site and may require further pain management.
* Nausea and vomiting: The patient is experiencing frequent nausea and vomiting, which may be related to her underlying disease or treatment.

Recommendations:

* Continue respiratory support with high-flow nasal cannula and 95% FiO2
* Monitor the patient's cardiac tamponade and pleural effusion closely
* Continue antibiotic treatment for RUL PNA
* Monitor the patient's anemia and consider transfusion if necessary
* Continue renal function monitoring and adjust treatment as necessary
* Monitor the patient's infection status and adjust treatment as necessary
* Continue pain management and consider alternative pain medications if necessary
* Consider adjusting the patient's nausea and vomiting treatment regimen if necessary.

   Assessment and Plan
   This is an 83 year old lady with a history of HTN, dyslipidemia and
   lung cancer who to OSH with SOB and low BP and found to have a large
   pericardial effusion with cardiac tamponade, likely of malignant
   etiology, for which she was transferred here for pericardiocentesis. On
   arrival there are few prior hospital records available. She underwent
   pericardiocentesis in the cath lab, and 600cc of bloody fluid were
   removed resulting in normalization of systemic and pulmonary pressures.
   Goals of care: Moving towards more comfort driven care.  Hoping to have
   her move to hospice.
   - Per nursing, has been approved to be moved to nh/hospice nearer to
   [**Hospital1 1233**].
   - Occasionally complains of pain at drain site, responds well to
   percocet.  Frequent nausea treated with Zofran and Phenergan.
   Cardiac Tamponade: s/p pericardiocentesis. Occasional respiratory
   distress with coughing, recovers well by calming down. Hemodynamically
   stable this morning in 90s-100s. Cytology from pericardial fluid
   negative for malignant cells.
   RUL PNA: Read as likely post-obstructive pneumonia, likely CAP. Remains
   afebrile, WBC trending down, remains afebrile.  Sputum culture shows
   rare yeast, but clinical picture does not fit systemic yeast infection.
   - day 5 of Levo/Flagyl for 10 day course.
   - follow fever curve and symptoms.
   - follow cultures (Blood pending, urine Ag Legionella neg, sputum cx
   rare yeast)
   R Pleural effusion: Malignant vs infectious. Given tenuous
   hemodynamics, will not diurese at this time.
   UTI: U/A with WBCs and bacteria likely represents an uncomplicated UTI,
   appropriately covered by Levofloxacin for likely PNA.  Cultures came
   back negative.
   -continue antibiotics
   Respiratory Distress: Extubated, RR 18 this morning w/ strong cough.
   Requiring 95% FiO2 on FM.  Most likely pneumonia and tumor burden in
   lungs. Responds to calming and suctioning
   -cont atrovent, albuterol nebs PRN
   Acid/Base Disturbance: ABG today pH 7.34/41/87/23 on FiO2 95%. ABG post
   cath showed pH 7.26, down from 7.34 in ED with a lactate of 1.3 and
   normal PCO2. Given hypotension in the setting of cardiac tamponade,
   this may reflects a resolving lactic acidosis along with respiratory
   alkalosis in the setting of respiratory distress.
   .
   Anemia: Likely due to acute blood loss in setting of pericardial
   effusion and drainage. Likely also baseline chronic anemia given that
   she was taking iron pills at home.  Hct has been stable, today 24.0.
   -stable, transfusion goal Hct>21.0
   .
   CORONARIES: No prior history of CAD and no CP during this episode.
   Cardiac enzymes negative for ACS.  Off simvastatin given comfort focus
   of care.
   RHYTHM: NSR since admission, no known h/o arrhythmia.
   -Monitor on tele
   .
   Presumed ARF: Seems to be resolved, Cre now 1.0. Baseline Cre unknown
   on admission, but a component of prerenal ARF is likely given
   hypotension in setting of tamponade.
   -follow Cre
   DM-2: Continue home basal lantus dose with SSI coverage.
   .
   FEN: S/S cleared for thins w/ crushed pills; replete lytes PRN.
   ACCESS: R PIV. No PICC placement as going to hospice.
   PROPHYLAXIS:
   -DVT ppx with Heparin SC
   -Pain management with APAP
   -Bowel regimen with senna/colace
   CODE: DNR /DNI, have not discussed Do-Not-Rehospitalize
   DISPO: CCU for now
   HCP: [**Name (NI) 186**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 8335**]; Daughter [**Telephone/Fax (1) 8336**]
